page.title: 02NATURAL HISTORY,LYDART
page.content: Lydart has many unspoilt areas which are havens for wildlife. Forestry Commission woods on a steep slope at 240 metres provide a home for a large badger population,foxes,polecats and fallow deer. Large areas of rough grazing,woodland edges and gardens are ideal for butterflies such as painted ladies, silver washed fritillaries,marbled whites,brimstones and holly blue. In the traditional pastures common wild flowers are cowslips,ragged robin,spotted orchids,wild daffodils, harebells,ox-eye daisies,early purple orchids and moschatel. Geology,too,is of interest. Bands of quartz conglomerate (pudding stone) are sandwiched between sandstone layers;there are many abandoned quarries in the woods and local walls show this mixture of stone.
